The Moor Frog (Rana arvalis) has a wide distribution across Europe, with a global distribution that extends to Asia. It is assessed as Least Concern for both Europe and for the EU 27 member states in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category, although declines have been noted for several states.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
It is threatened by the destruction and pollution of breeding ponds (including acidification) and adjacent wetland and terrestrial habitats, especially through urbanisation, recreation, tourism, industry and overstocking of cattle.

Additional threats are prolonged drought and predation of spawn by waterfowl, Wild Boar and Common Buzzard (B. Halpern pers. obs. October 2022).

Chytrid fungus was first detected in this species in Germany (Mutschmann et al. 2000) and then later in Poland (Czeczuga et al. 2014). Reshetnikov (2001) found that the introduced fish Perccottus glenii strongly prey on the tadpoles of the Moor Frog, causing strong decline in the number of local populations in Russia.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation in Place
It is listed on Appendix II the Bern Convention and on Appendix IV of the EU Habitats Directive.

The species is protected by national legislation in many countries and is recorded in several national and sub-national Red Data books and lists. It is considered Endangered in Switzerland (Schmidt et al. 2023), Vulnerable in Slovenia (Anonymous 2010) and Romania (Botnariuc and Tatole 2005), Near Threatened in Czechia (Chobot and Něměc 2017), Austria (Gollmann 2007) and Sweden (ArtDatabanken 2020). In some other national Red Lists, such as Denmark (Aarhus Universitet 2019).

The Agile Frog is present in many protected areas. Conservation initiatives involving head-starting have been undertaken for the small Jersey population which have been remarkably successful. In parts of its range, mitigation measures to reduce road kill have been established. In Spain, it is an endangered species (Pleguezuelos et al. 2002) and there are habitat restoration and population monitoring efforts ongoing. In some parts of its range, there have been successful efforts to restore pond habitats.

There were eight EC-funded LIFE-projects targeting the species or its habitats: https://webgate.ec.europa.eu/life/publicWebsite/search/get?basicSearchText=rana+dalmatina

Conservation Needed
Water management should target the restoration of water bodies, serving as breeding habitat for the species throughout its range, but especially within EU Natura 2000 network.

Research Needed
Monitoring of populations for the presence and effects of Bd infection or other emerging pathogens need to be organised throughout its range (Kostanjšek et al. 2021).
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: It inhabits the zone of European deciduous forests, either within the forests or in the adjacent meadows (Speybroeck et al. 2016). It generally it does not occur in pasture, arable areas or coniferous forests. In Spain the species is restricted to Quercus pedunculata oak forest, and is associated with wet meadows. It spawns in small wetlands (pools, fens and marshes, ditches) within forests and at their edges. High levels of larval mortality have been recorded.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is a relatively abundant species, however, the population trend is suspected to be declining. The species is common in much of central, eastern and southeastern Europe (e.g. Hungary, Romania, the former Yugoslavian countries). It is scarce to uncommon in northern Europe (e.g. Sweden, Denmark). In Spain, it is extremely rare within its small area of occurrence.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is widely distributed throughout central, and Western Europe, the Apennine Peninsula, southeastern Europe, the entire Balkan Peninsula, including European Türkiye (Thrace), a number of isolated populations in southern Scandinavia, the Channel island of Jersey (GB), a small part of Poland and southernmost parts of Ukraine (Heatwole and Wilkinson 2015). It is absent from the Iberian Peninsula, except Álava, Burgos and Navarra Provinces in northern Spain (Gosá and Bergerandi 1994). It has been introduced to Drenthe, the Netherlands (not mapped; Speybroeck et al. 2016). It occurs from sea level to elevations approaching 1,700 m asl. The area of occupancy (AOO) has not been estimated but is presumed to be large, and the extent of occurrence (EEO) are also large, at both EU 27 and pan Europe scales.

Out of the Europe region, the species extends to northern parts of Anatolia in Türkiye (Baran et al. 2021).
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

The Agile Frog (Rana dalmatina) is near-endemic to Europe. It is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: It is generally but locally threatened by the drainage and eutrophication of breeding sites, development (and logging) of suitable habitat, and replacement of deciduous forest habitat with unsuitable coniferous species. It is locally threatened by road mortality during breeding migrations. It is experiencing localised declines in southwestern Europe. In the Balkan peninsula, it is one of the amphibian species jeopardised by uncontrolled establishment of run-of-river small hydropower plants (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2021).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species has been utilised for local subsistence in parts of its range (e.g., Szilárd and Csengele 2001), which is thought to be causing local declines, however, the current occurrence and extent of harvest is not known.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in many protected areas. It is listed on Appendix III of the Berne Convention and on Annex V of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It has been recorded in a number of national and sub-national Red Data books and lists and is protected by national legislation in a number of countries. It is considered Vulnerable in Czech Republic (Chobot and Nemec 2017), Slovenia (Anonymous 2010), Romania (Botnariuc and Tatole 2005) and Greece (Legakis and Maragou 2009), Near Threatened in Austria (Gollmann 2007), Hungary (Halpern et al. 2019), Bosnia and Herzegovina (Đug 2013) and Serbia (Kalezić et al. 2015). In parts of its range, mitigation measures to reduce road kill have been established (see in: Schmidt et al. 2020). There were six EC-funded LIFE-projects targeting the species or its habitats: https://webgate.ec.europa.eu/life/publicWebsite/search/get basicSearchText=rana+temporaria

Evidence shows that successful conservation action is possible for this species (Moor et al. 2022).

Conservation Needed
Water management should target the restoration of water bodies, serving as breeding habitat for the species throughout its range, but especially within EU Natura 2000 network.

Research Needed
Monitoring of populations for the presence and effects of Bd infection or other emerging pathogens need to be organised throughout its range.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: Many terrestrial (associated with woodland) and aquatic habitat types are used. It is present in coniferous, mixed and deciduous forests, forested tundra and steppe, bush and shrublands, glades, grasslands, dry and wet meadows, marshes, fields, rural gardens, parks, and urban areas. Aquatic habitats include both temporary and permanent ponds, lakes and rivers; spawning and larval development occurs in these waterbodies. It does well in many modified habitats such as rural gardens.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The Common Frog is generally very common, although localised declines have recently been noted in a number of western European countries (e.g.. Germany, Switzerland, Spain). It is considered to be stable in Italy (F. Ficetola and R. Maneneti pers. comm. September 2020).
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is widespread throughout most of Europe, ranging from northern Spain to the Urals (absent from southern and central Iberia, much of southern Italy [scattered Apennine subpopulations]), eastwards to European Russia and through northern Greece and Bulgaria. It has a patchy distribution in the mountainous parts of the Balkans. It has been recorded from sea level to elevations approaching 2,700 m asl (Pyrenees).

The range extends eastwards of the European region to the western part of West Siberia and northern Kazakhstan.

Following genetic analysis, subpopulations from northwestern Spain have been assigned to Rana parvipalmata which was elevated from the subspecies of this species (Dufresnes et al. 2020).
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

The European Common Frog (Rana temporaria) is assessed as Least Concern for both Europe and for the EU 27 member states in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: There are no major threats to this species. The main localised threat is the general pollution and drainage of breeding sites and wetlands. Over-collection for medical research, food and commercial purposes is a threat in parts of its range. Deforestation might have led to a gradual "northward retreat" of the species over southern parts of its distribution. In the Balkan Peninsula it is one of the amphibian species jeopardised by uncontrolled establishment of run-of-river small hydropower plants (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2021). In Germany the species has been suffering from the spring drought for several years due to its choice of very shallow spawning grounds (U. Schulte pers. comm. October 2022). Rana temporaria is probably declining in Slovakia, as it is disappearing from lower elevation, being replaced by R. dalmatina (D. Jablonski pers. comm. October 2022). Overcollection for medical research has been a threat in the past, however the extent to which it is a current threat is unknown. The introduction of fish to freshwater systems is a threat for this species (Schmidt et al. 2021). For example, introduced fish Perccottus glenii strongly prey tadpoles of this species causing strong decline in the number of local populations in Russia (Reshetnikov 2001).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: Over-collection for medical research, food and commercial purposes is a threat to this species.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati: It occurs in a number of protected areas in Iberia, but there is a need to monitor vulnerable populations in northern and eastern Spain and Portugal. It is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention and is protected by national legislation in Spain, where captive breeding of the species and habitat restoration projects are in place in some regions.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This is a highly aquatic species of Mediterranean-type habitats including scrub, open woodland and cultivated land. It is generally found in ponds, dayas, wadi, lakes, ditches and slow-moving streams (often temporary in nature) with plenty of vegetation cover. The adults are mostly found under stones or in mud in their aquatic habitats or sheltering under cover on land if the wetland dries up. It may be present in slightly modified aquatic and terrestrial habitats. The female deposits around 800–1,500 eggs on plants and stones in ponds.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is not abundant over most of its distribution, with populations being more scattered and fragmented in the east and north of the Iberian Peninsula. Some population declines in this species have been observed, especially in eastern Spain.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
Within the European region, this species is distributed in central and southern Iberia and in part of an external Spanish territory in North Africa (Ceuta). It has been introduced to Gibraltar, but this population appears "not to have prospered" (D. Doonaire-Barroso pers. comm. 2020). In southern Portugal and Andalusia (Spain), it is the most widespread salamander (D. Donaire pers. comm. 2020). It is essentially a lowland species becoming rare above 900 m asl, although it might be found at 1,565 m asl in the Sierra de Loja, Granada, Spain. This species has a low dispersal capacity, resulting in strong genetic structure at small spatial scales (I. Martinez-Solano pers. comm. November 2019).

Out of the European region, this species occurs in the coastal plain of northern Morocco.
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Near Threatened (NT)
EU 27 regional assessment: Near Threatened (NT)

This species is listed as Near Threatened because this species is probably in significant decline (but probably at a rate of slightly less than 30% over three generations) because of widespread habitat loss through much of its range, and the effects of invasive species, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: This species is generally threatened by the loss of aquatic habitats through drainage, agrochemical pollution, the impacts of livestock (in North African dayas), eutrophication, domestic and industrial contamination, and infrastructure development. It has largely disappeared from coastal areas in Iberia and Morocco close to concentrations of tourism and highly populated areas (such as Madrid). Introduced fish and crayfish (Procambarus clarkii) are known to prey on the eggs and larvae of this species and are implicated in its decline. There is a supposed need to include non-amphibian hosts, especially invasive species such as the red swamp crayfish, as part of the dynamics of Bd infection in order to predict possible outbreaks of chytridiomycosis, as well as its contemplation in future conservation strategies on amphibians (Oficialdegui et al. 2019). Mortality on roads has been reported to be a serious threat to some populations.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There is no information available.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati: The species is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention and is protected by national legislation in Spain. It is not known if this species occurs in any protected areas.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: It is generally restricted to humid montane forests where it is found under stones and beneath roots in Cedar (Cedrus) and Oak (Quercus) woodland. It has also been observed in caves in parts of its range. This salamander appears to be ovoviviparous over most of its distribution (8-50 eggs are produced), but viviparous in the Tangitana region of Morocco. In general, the females produce 15-16 larvae; the larvae may be deposited in either cisterns or small streams.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This is generally a very rare species, especially in Algeria. However, it is locally common in the central and western Rif Mountains in Morocco. It is possibly extinct on Beni Snassen Mountain in north-eastern Morocco.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
Within the European region, this species is restricted to Ceuta (Spanish North African Territory; Martinez et al. 1997, Mateo et al. 2003) on the Mediterranean coast of North Africa.

This species is restricted to northwest Africa (Salvador 1996, Ben Hassine et al. 2016), with a fragmented range in parts of northern Morocco (Rif and Moyen Atlas; Bogaerts 2000, Donaire Barroso and Bogaerts 2001, Bogaerts and Donaire-Barroso 2003, Beukema et al. 2013), and northern Algeria (coastal mountain ranges; Bogaerts and Donaire-Barroso 1999, Bouzid et al. 2017, Beddek et al. 2018). There is an uncertain record (based on a museum voucher specimen) of this species from northern Tunisia; the presence of Salamandra algira in Tunisia requires further verification. The species has a global altitudinal range of approximately 80-2,450 m asl.
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Not Applicable (NA)
EU 27 regional assessment: Not Applicable (NA)

In the European Red List region, occurrence is restricted to the Spanish North African Territory of Ceuta. It is therefore Not Applicable for the European Red List.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: The species occurs in small relict populations that are heavily threatened by deforestation, overgrazing by domestic livestock, and channelisation of water sources for irrigation. The species is locally threatened by mortality on roads, and there is some collection of this species in small numbers for the international pet trade; further investigations are needed to determine the impact of trade on populations.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This salamander is captured by specimen collectors and features in the pet trade. There are captive populations of this species and the ratio of wild captured to captive-bred specimens in trade requires further investigation.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
While this species is still not listed as a separate species on Appendix II of the Bern Convention nor on Annexes II and IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive, it is included under the previous name - T. karelinii. It is protected by national legislations and is listed as EN in the national Red List of North Macedonia under the name of T. karelinii (Sterijovski and Arsovski 2020), as VU in the national Red Data Books of Serbia (Kalezić et al. 2015) and as Near Threatened in Greece (Sotiropoulos 2010). It is present in some protected areas in Türkiye.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species' habitat and ecological requirements resemble those of Triturus karelinii. It can be found in mountain forests (broad-leaved and coniferous species) and their surroundings; the forest steppe and even true steppe sites within the mountains. The species can withstand some degree of habitat modification. In breeding season, it prefers relatively deep slow-moving stream pools, ponds and occasionally drainage ditches. The female deposits approximately 100-250 eggs into water.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species is sporadically distributed over much of its range (although common in suitable habitats). Its population trend is considered to be stable in most of the distribution area (N. Uzum pers. comm. May 2019).
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
In Europe, this species encompasses the south-eastern Balkan Peninsula, covering most of Bulgaria, the eastern parts of Greece (eastern Macedonia and Thrace regions; Pafilis and Maragou 2020), North Macedonia, as well as European Türkiye. An isolated distribution pocket is found in Serbia that is disconnected from the main range by other intervening Triturus species (T. cristatus in the north and T. macedonicus in the south; Arntzen and Wallis 1999, Litvinchuk et al. 1999, Wielstra and Arntzen 2012, Wielstra et al. 2013, Wielstra et al. 2014).

Its global distribution extends to Asiatic Türkiye, along the coast of the Aegean Sea and the western part of the Marmara Sea (Wielstra and Arntzen 2016).
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This species is assessed as Least Concern for both Europe and the EU 27 member states in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
Although it is widespread and found in many habitat types, deforestation and destruction of wetlands caused by urbanisation, industrial and agrochemical pollution appear to be the main threats to this species’ range. In the Balkans, there has been loss of breeding habitats in recent years due to decreased spring rains, perhaps as a result of global climate change, but anthropogenic impact in terms of intentional drying out these aquatic habitats cannot be neglected (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2005, Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2022). Similarly, in Türkiye the loss of aquatic habitats is a serious threat to many amphibian species, including also T. ivanbureschi (Olgun and Üzüm 2015). Other major threats in for this species are habitat alterations via construction activities and new roads (K. Olgun pers. comm. 2018).

In Greece, the main threats are the loss of aquatic habitats due to agrochemical pollution, drainage and fish introductions and habitat fragmentation due to land use changes and urbanization. Especially in northern Greece, there is heavy contamination and pollution of surface water due to agriculture (Gikas et al. 2013). As a forest-dwelling amphibian species that is sensitive to changes in their surrounding ecosystem, forest fires and climate change could lead to loss of suitable habitats for the species (Kafash et al. 2018). Possible threat is the emergence of chytrid pathogens, although there are no current records of infections in this species within Greece (Azmanis et al. 2016).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati: It is listed on Annexes II and IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive, and on Revised Annex I of Resolution 6 (1998; species requiring specific habitat conservation measures) and on Appendix II and III of the Bern Convention. It is listed in a number of national and sub-national Red Data Books and Lists. It is recorded from many protected areas across its range in Crimea.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
It can be found in mountain forests (broad-leaved and coniferous species) and their surroundings. The majority of such populations are the relics of a former forest fauna. Within these landscapes, these populations inhabit slopes and plateau covered with meadows or xerophytic vegetation. Such habitats are especially widespread in the parts of the species' range in Crimea. In general, T. karelinii seems to be more resistant to xeric habitat conditions than other Triturus newts.

Breeding takes place in slow moving stream pools, ponds and occasionally drainage ditches. The female deposits approximately 100-250 eggs; these are individually wrapped in aquatic vegetation. The species can withstand some degree of habitat modification.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: Habitat loss has caused the decline of many populations in Crimea.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
In Europe, this species inhabits the southernmost parts of Crimea (Ukraine). The highest locality in Crimea is the Chuchel' Mount (1,200 m asl) (Litvinchuk and Borkin 2009).

Out of Europe, this species distribution area broadly follows Caucasus mountain range, Russia (southern European Russia out of the European Red List region), Georgia and Azerbaijan), spreading there to the southern parts of the Russian Federation on the north, and to Türkiye to the south, and with a disjunct enclave on the north in Iran. There are apparently isolated populations on the Crimean Peninsula, and in the southern Caspian region of northern Iran. The map for this species largely follows Wielstra et al. (2014), and Wielstra and Arntzen (2016). It can be found from sea level to elevations approaching 2,100 m asl (southern Caucasus).
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Not Recorded

In the European region, the Southern Crested Newt (Triturus karelinii) is restricted to southern Crimea. It is assessed as Least Concern for the European region as, although its area of occupancy (AOO) and extent of occurrence (EOO) are moderately restricted, the Southern Crested Newt (Triturus karelinii) is tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category. It does not occur in the EU27 Member States.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: Deforestation and pollution of wetlands by agrochemicals appear to be the main threats to this species. In the former Soviet Union there is significant commercial collecting of this species for the pet trade.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is collected for the national and international pet trade.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati: This species occurs in several protected areas.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: The species occurs in a wide-variety of habitats including rocky and stony areas, meadows, cork oak groves, Mediterranean scrub, and agricultural land and sometimes in urban areas. It breeds in fresh or brackish still or slow-flowing waterbodies. The females deposit approximately 5,000-10,000 eggs. During the day the adults of this species hide under rocks or in tunnels.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This is a generally abundant species.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
Within the European region, this species is known from an introduced subpopulation in Andalusia, southern mainland Spain, close to the Parque Natural los Alcornocales, and from the North African Spanish territories of Melilla and Ceuta, where it is native.

Globally, this species has a fragmented range (there is a small area of occupancy within the wide extent of occurrence) in Morocco, northern Algeria, Tunisia and the North African Spanish territories of Melilla and Ceuta. Apparently isolated populations in northern Niger and northern Mali refer to Sclerophrys xeros (U. Joger pers. comm.). It is not confirmed from Western Sahara, although it might occur in the extreme north (Geniez et al. 2000). The species range from around sea level up to 2,650 m asl in the Atlas Mountains.
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Not Applicable (NA)
EU 27 regional assessment: Not Applicable (NA)

The Moroccan Toad (Sclerophrys mauritanica) occurs as native in the European assessment region only in the Spanish North African enclaves of Ceuta and Melilla, with an introduced population in in southern mainland Spain. It is considered Not Applicable on the basis of marginal occurrence for both Europe and the EU 27 member states.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: There are generally no major threats to this widespread and adaptable species. Loss of suitable habitat and pollution resulting from development, and mortality through road kill are localised threats to some populations.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati: This species occurs in numerous protected areas, including State Nature Park "Karagadsky" and State Nature Park "Opukskiy" in the Crimea. Research is required to confirm the distribution of the species, and to understand the impact of threats.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: Mostly found in flat and open lowlands with loose soils, but also in human-altered habitats such as quarries, agricultural areas (Speybroeck et al. 2016). It is a highly specialised burrowing and nocturnal species, with a narrow ecological niche. Preferred breeding sites are quite deep and permanent waters, nutrient and vegetation rich (Speybroeck et al. 2016).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is a widespread species (Kuzmin 1999, Dufresnes et al. 2019). The population is considered to be relatively stable.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
In the European region, this species occurs in South European Russia and in Ukraine (northeastern and eastern Ukraine and Crimea) (Litvinchuk et al. 2013, Speybroeck et al. 2016). It is widespread from the contact zone with Pelobates fuscus, to and along the Ural River (Kuzmin 1999, Dufresnes et al. 2019), however, the exact limits with P. fuscus are not known in the northern 700 km of the distribution range (Dufresnes et al. 2019). Detailed genetic data showed that the transition extends between the Kursk region to southern Ukraine (Litvinchuk et al. 2013, Dufresnes et al. 2019). The elevation range in the European region is not known.

Out of the European region, the range extends southwards to the northern foothills of the Caucasus and northwards to extreme southwestern Western Siberia and northwestern Kazakhstan (Frost 2021). It occurs at elevations between the Caspian Sea level (-28 m) and 830 m asl in the Caucasus (Dufresnes et al. 2019).
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Not Recorded

In the European region, this species is known from Ukraine and parts of European Russia. It is assessed as assessed as Least Concern for Europe in view of its wide distribution and presumed large and stable population. It is not recorded in the EU 27 member states.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
This species overwinters underground, burrowing down to 1.5 m or deeper and has poor frost tolerance – it is unable to withstand temperatures below 0 °C (Bulakhova et al. 2020), which means that keeping the quality of the soil is very important, and habitat alterations could cause great harm to local populations of wetlands by industry, domestic sewage and agriculture (including eutrophication), drainage of breeding pools and introduction of predatory fishes and crayfish are major threats to the species. The species is also impacted by the loss of terrestrial habitats (such as meadows) by factors such as intensive agriculture (e.g., over-stocking of cattle) and mortality on roads (and off-road driving).

The species is collected in small numbers for the pet trade.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is traded in small numbers in the international pet trade.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in many protected areas.

Research Needed
Taxonomic research is required to fully understand this species' relationship with X. l. victorianus and X. l. sudanensis.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: It is a water-dependent species occurring in a very wide range of habitats, including heavily modified anthropogenic habitats, providing there are semi-permanent bodies of water present (B. Evans pers. comm. January 2017). It lives in all sorts of waterbodies, including streams, but tends to avoid large rivers, and waterbodies with predatory fish. It reaches its highest densities in eutrophic water. This species breeds in water; though there are no records of it breeding in flowing water. It has very high reproductive potential and is highly opportunistic, colonising newly recreated, apparently isolated, waterbodies with ease. It can migrate in large numbers when breeding ponds start to dry up and the weather is wet.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This species is extremely abundant.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is introduced to the European region. It has been introduced to parts of the United Kingdom (in south Wales and the Isle of Wight, and a number of occasional records from other locations) but now thought to be extirpated, France (the Departments of Deux-Sèvres and Maine et Loire), Portugal (the Lage stream, about 20 km west of Lisbon; Rebelo et al. 2007) and Italy (a large invasive population on Sicily; Lillo et al. 2005, Faraone et al. 2008). Introduced subpopulations in Wales and Lincolnshire are now thought to have completely disappeared, which is the first documented case of introduced amphibians disappearing (Tinsley et al. 2015).

The global range of this species is unclear following the removal of Xenopus victorianus from X. laevis. For the purposes of this assessment we have assumed that all animals from southern Angola, Zambia, Malawi and Mozambique southwards (including in almost all of Zimbabwe, Botswana, Namibia, South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland) belong to X. laevis. All individuals in Nigeria, Cameroon, Central African Republic, and the Democratic Republic of Congo west of 28ºE were previously attributed to X. l. sudanensis. However, subpopulations from Nigeria, Cameroon and Central African Republic have now been assigned to Xenopus poweri (Furman et al. 2015). It is also thought that individuals of the subspecies from Adamawa Region in Cameroon could be a synonym of Xenopus poweri, but additional data from type localities or examination of the type specimens is required for confirmation (Furman et al. 2015). Records from Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo east of 28º E refer to X. victorianus. There is an isolated record from Gabon (M. Beier pers. comm. January 2006). This species ranges from sea-level up to 3,000 m asl.

It is introduced in several places outside its native range, including the USA where it was first introduced in the 1930s and 1940s for laboratory use and later as an aquarium pet. It was introduced and established locally in California (San Diego, Orange, Riverside, Los Angeles, Ventura, and Imperial counties) and Arizona (Tucson area) (Stebbins 1985, Lafferty and Page 1997). It has been recorded from, but it is not established in Colorado. It has also been introduced to Chile (introduced in the 1970s to central Chile, Valparaiso to Concepción Provinces), and Java (Indonesia). It is presumed to occur in southwestern Sudan, but there do not appear to be confirmed records from this country (there is an uncertain record assigned to X. l. sudanensis from Jebel Marrah, Sudan (M. Beier pers. comm. January 2006). Records from Congo refer to X. petersii. Its range is also extending in parts of Africa, often by introduction because it is used for live bait, and it has spread extensively in South Africa.
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Not Applicable (NA)
EU 27 regional assessment: Not Applicable (NA)

This species is listed as Not Applicable for the European Red List as it has been introduced to the region.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
This species is very successful and adaptable, and is an invasive species in many areas. Studies show that it is not impacted by the herbicide atrazine. It is utilised for food and for research purposes, but not at levels that constitute a major threat to the species.

Chytridiomycosis was detected in museum specimens of this species dating back to 1938, and it is hypothesised that the international trade in this species might have introduced this fungal disease to other regions of the world. The disease does not appear to have any detrimental effect on populations of this species. Further, ongoing export of live X. laevis from South Africa may be of conservation concern, not for X. laevis populations in South Africa but for populations of other frogs worldwide given that X. laevis is a vector for the pathogenic fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (D.C. Blackburn pers. comm. November 2012).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: The species is harvested and traded both for human consumption and research.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
There are no measures required to conserve this species. Instead, eradication of this species from its introduced range is a conservation priority. In Asia, this species is believed to have a negative impact on the native amphibian fauna. It should be monitored and controlled. Farming activities should concentrate on native Rana rugulosa. Farming of Rana catesbeiana should at least be strictly contained, including water discharges from farms that should be carefully controlled or prevented. Ideally, the farming of the species outside its range should be prohibited. Studies of actual and potential ecological impacts should be conducted, perhaps leading to an elimination programme. Awareness of the potential threat posed by this species to native biodiversity must be raised.

The Venezuelan government has taken actions to avoid the spread of this species. There has been an eradication program, with participants from the University of Los Andes at Mérida, the Venezuelan Institute of Scientific Research (IVIC) and the Ministry of Environment, instated at the beginning of 2002.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species inhabits ponds, swamps, lakes, reservoirs, marshes, stream margins and irrigation ditches. It is sometimes found in temporary waters hundreds of metres from permanent water. It winters at the bottom of pools. It may disperse from water in wet weather. Eggs and larvae develop in permanent slow or non-flowing bodies of water.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
There are thousands of occurrences of this species. It is highly abundant and its global population is increasing. Although some of the populations in Europe of this species are increasing, other introductions not have become fully established.

In Asia, it is only present in isolated pockets. Animals have been deliberately introduced to northern Thailand in the hope of augmenting native frog production. Farmed animals are exported alive to East Asia (Pariyanonth and Daorerk 1995, Lim and Lim 1992) and can escape or be released to become established. A growing population is now established in the Venezuelan Andes (C. Gottberg and A. Diaz pers. comm.), near the town of Jají, in Mérida State.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
In Europe, where it is introduced, the largest population occurs within the Po River Valley (Italy) where formal introductions continued at least until 1937. Other introduced subpopulations have been reported from Belgium (recorded from several sites in Wallonia and at least one population is known in Flanders), the Netherlands, central and southwestern France, Germany (in the vicinity of Bonn and also in Baden-Württemberg), Greece (Crete), Spain (Gran Canaria in the Canary Islands, Villasbuenas de Gata in Cacerés [not recently observed and Sierra de Collserola, Cataluña Province [only a few individuals observed]), and the United Kingdom (possibly now eradicated). It has possibly been introduced to Switzerland, although this requires further confirmation.

This is a very wide-ranging species. Its native range is from Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, southern Quebec, Canada, south to eastern North America, except southern Florida, USA, then southward through Veracruz, Mexico. It is also found in Sinaloa, and probably other areas in Mexico, as well. This species was introduced to Mexico at the beginning of the last century. It was introduced to 'La Garita' in Costa Rica but now appears to be extinct in this country (G. Chaves pers. comm.). It is also introduced in Cuba, Puerto Rico (introduced 1935), Hawaii (introduced mid- to late 1800s, now on all main islands), Isla de la Juventud, Hispaniola (only confirmed in northern and eastern Dominican Republic, not in Haiti) and Jamaica. Its range is increasing in some areas.

The species is introduced to South America. In Venezuela, there is an expanding population near La Azulita, in Mérida state, at the Andean versants facing Lake Maracaibo basin. In Colombia, it is known from the Middle Magdalena Valley, north to the lowlands on the Caribbean coast. It has also been found in Bogotá, although it is not known whether it has established a population there. In Peru, it has become established around Iquitos in central Loreto Department in the Amazon Basin, and also around Lima on the Pacific coast. There are also a number of populations established in Ecuador and Brazil. It has been introduced in Rincón de Pando, Canelones, Uruguay, and in Misiones, Argentina. In Asia, where it is also introduced, it is found in several localities in the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and Singapore. It has also been introduced to mainland China and Taiwan, Province of China, for raising in farms for human consumption. Feral populations have become established in Taiwan, Province of China, Kunming in Yunnan province, Sichuan, Xinjiang and possibly other places in China as a result of escape or deliberate release. Individuals have been found in the wild in Hong Kong probably from releases of market animals. However, there is no evidence to suggest that this species is now established in Hong Kong. It is found widely from southern Hokkaido to Ishigakijima in Japan.

European regional assessment: Not Applicable (NA)
EU 27 regional assessment: Not Applicable (NA)

This species is a recent introduction to the European region and is therefore classified as Not Applicable for the European Red List.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: There are no threats to this species. Outside its native range, this species is considered a pest. It has been observed predating on native species in Puerto Rico, including on Leptodactylus albilabris, and is a potential predator of other native species throughout its introduced range. It is a possible vector of pathogens.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: The species is commercially farmed in several of the countries where it has been introduced.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is present in many protected areas. It is listed in the Red Data Books of the Middle Urals (Perm and Sverdlovsk provinces of Russia).

Research Needed
Surveys to determine the current population size, status and trends are recommended.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is found in wet coniferous, mixed, deciduous forests in the taiga zone and riparian groves in tundra and forest steppe. In forests, it is mostly found in glades and along the edges of woods not far from stagnant or semi-flowing waters. It is more rarely found in meadows, willow stands, fields, suburban and urban areas. In the Polar Urals, the species is found on the shores of small lakes surrounded with swamps in shrubby and sedge-shrubby tundras. In the forest steppe region it is found in marshes in meadows, meadow steppes and small-leafed forests. It breeds by larval development in ditches, pools, and slow-flowing streams, with breeding season occurring April to early June.  It preys on insects, molluscs and earthworms.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This species is generally common over its moderately wide range in Europe.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
Within the European region, this species ranges from the north of European Russia (Arkhangelskaya Province) to the Ural Mountains and in the south Kostroma and Nizhniy Novgorod provinces and Udmurtia and Komi republics.

Globally, this species is widespread across Asiatic parts of Russia, and also occurs in northern China, northern Mongolia and Kazakhstan, on the islands of Sakhalin, Kunashir (Russia) and on Hokkaido (Japan). Globally, it has an elevational range between 2-2,250 m asl (Speybroeck et al. 2016).
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Not Recorded

In the European region, this species is restricted to northern parts of European Russia. It is assessed as Least Concern for Europe in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats and presumed large population. It is not recorded from the EU 27 member states.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
This species is locally threatened by the desiccation of wetlands, loss of terrestrial habitat, pollution, increased urbanisation, and the construction of roads and mega-solar power plants.

Specimens of this species tested negative for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Civiš et al. 2013).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in many protected areas.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is found in a range of mostly sunny, well-vegetated habitats, commonly consisting of hedges, bramble or reedbeds, or meadows with extensive herbaceous vegetation (Speybroeck et al. 2016, describing a group containing Hyla arborea, H. intermedia and H. molleri as well as H. orientalis). This or related species have been found as high as 10 m in trees, but animals are generally found lower (Speybroeck et al. 2016). In the Russian Kaliningrad Province it inhabits lightly forested and bushy areas along the banks of small reservoirs among agricultural lands, thickets of shrubs and tall grasses along the banks of ditches, wet meadows with shrubs, garden plots (S.N. Litvinchuk and D.V. Skorinov pers. obs. October 2022). It can make use of "a large variety" of waterbodies as breeding sites, but favours sun-exposed, well-vegetated and fish free breeding sites in standing water or stagnant sections of rivers (Speybroeck et al. 2016). Favoured sites for frogs within this group include marshes and well-vegetated areas of lake or stagnant river sections, but anthropogenic sites such as quarry ponds or disused swimming pools may be used (Speybroeck et al. 2016). It is generally nocturnal, but may be active by day in warm, humid conditions or at high elevations (Speybroeck et al. 2016). It may be active year-round in southern parts of the range, with reproduction taking place in winter and metamorphosis in early summer (Speybroeck et al. 2016). In the temperate regions, breeding starts in the mid-spring. Clutches consist of up to (but usually fewer than) 100 eggs, with a single female laying as many as 50 clutches in a night, each anchored to vegetation (Speybroeck et al. 2016). A female may lay as many as 1,400 eggs during a single season (Speybroeck et al. 2016).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: There are no specific information on population status of this species in the countries of its main occurrence in Europe. In the 1980's, the species became extinct in southwestern Russia in Belgorod Province (Lada et al. 2011); in Kursk Province it became extinct since the 1960's, and recently is extremely rare (Lada et al. 2002, Degtyarev 2021).
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
Within the European region (Frost 2021), this species occurs from European Türkiye and northeastern Greece (Evros prefecture; Speybroeck et al. 2016, Pafilis and Maragou 2020), parts of western Bulgaria, southeastern-eastern Serbia, Romania, Ukraine, Poland, north to the Baltic states (Lithuania and western Latvia), Belarus, and European Russia (Dufresnes et al. 2020), and eastwards through Ukraine (including the southern coast of Ukraine) to southwestern Russia. It is also known from several Greek islands in the Eastern Aegean, including Samothraki, Lesbos, Chios, Samos, Kos and Rhodes (Speybroeck et al. 2016; E.-A. Toli, Greece national Red List). The elevational range of the species in Europe is not well-characterised, but Speybroeck et al. (2016) state that "Southern species" in this group (which include the Common and Italian tree frogs) reach elevations over 2,000 m asl.

Out of the European region the range extends to Anatolian Türkiye (Gül et al. 2012, Baran et al. 2021), east to the Russian Northern Caucasus, and northern and central Armenia. It occurs disjunctly in the Talysh Mountains of Iran (Gilan, Mazandaran and Golestan provinces), and Azerbaijan.
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This species is widespread in Europe, and is assessed as Least Concern for both Europe and for the EU 27 member states in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: The threats are similar to those listed for H. arborea in the countries where both species occur: habitat alteration, urbanisation, conversion of natural habitats to agricultural ones without preserving enough suitable patches of original habitat. For breeding sites, the general threat is climate change (at least in the part of Serbia where this species has been detected, the sun-exposed and shallow small aquatic habitats dry out in warm years before tadpoles metamorphose), as well as the destruction of breeding sites as "useless" and their conversion to arable land or urban areas (J. Crnobrnja-Isailović pers. comm. January 2022). The threats mentioned for H. arborea in Serbia apply also to H. orientalis (see Crnobrnja-Isailović and Paunović 2015). In southwestern Russia, the main threat for the species is climate desiccation (Lada et al. 2011).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no specific data on use of this species for food or medicine, nor in the pet trade.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Hyla savignyi is protected by national law 153/2003 for the protection of environment; it is included in annex IV of Directive 92/43 (Lymberakis et al. 2015).

Research Needed
Population biology, threats, and trends.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: Despite that this species occurs in much drier landscapes than Hyla arborea, in Cyprus it normally inhabit places close to aquatic habitats such as streams, ponds, dams and lakes (Lymberakis et al. 2015). It is also present in gardens, bush lands, montane forest edges, open oak and juniper forests, and areas with permanent or semi permanent water sources (including oasis) with good surrounding vegetation (e.g. Phragmites, Oleander). The species is able to adapt to light habitat modification, and may be found in rural, agricultural (including paddy fields) or semi-urban, areas where suitable wetland habitat exists. Spawning and larval development takes place in small stagnant waterbodies, drainage canals and slow flowing brooks with dense herbaceous and shrub vegetation. In Cyprus, mating starts at the beginning of spring. Adult males can be heard calling until mid June also during day time. Eggs can be found into April. Spawning and development of the larvae take place in still or slow moving water. The metamorphosed frogs (SVL about 18 mm) can be found in May (Baier et al. 2009).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This species is relatively common in suitable habitat, and it is suspected to have a stable population trend.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
Within the European region, this species is restricted to Cyprus, where it is widespread throughout the island. It occurs at elevations from sea level to 1,600 m asl (www.herpatlas.cy).

Most of the range of this species is out of the European region. It occurs from extreme northwestern Sinai (Egypt), through Israel, Lebanon, Syria and southern and eastern Türkiye to the western part of Iran, Iraq, and Armenia, southern Georgia and Azerbaijan (Gvoždík et al. 2010; Dufresnes et al. 2019). It is present from on elevation from the sea level to above 2,100 m asl (Iran) (B. Safaei-Mahroo pers. comm. 2020).
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

In the European region, this species only occurs on Cyprus, however it is present across the island in a range of habitats and its population trend is thought to be stable. It is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, and presumed large and stable population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: Severe drought, exhausting water use, overgrazing, habitat modification and loss, introduction of alien fish and other species, insect control practice through spraying insecticides along small water bodies; potential future threat might be amphibian chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis) (Lymberakis et al. 2015).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati: Presence of the species in the Spanish North African territories requires confirmation.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: Habitat usage in Melilla, if present, is not known. It is generally fossorial, inhabiting lowland sandy uncultivated soils, sometimes in the vicinity of cork woodlands. The spawning sites are most often still temporary waterbodies (such as dayas and rain puddles). It does not occur in anthropogenically modified habitats.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: There is no information on the population status of this species, although it is believed to be declining.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
In the European Red List assessment region, Yus Ramos and Cabo Hernandez (1986) mentioned the presence of Pelobates cultripes in the Melilla region (Spain), which might refer to P. varaldii, though this record is far outside the known range of any Pelobates species and requires confirmation.

This species is known only from fragmented localised areas on the coastal plains of north-western Morocco (Pasteur and Bons 1959, Dorda 1984, Salvador 1996, Schleich et al. 1996, Busack et al. 1985, Bons and Geniez 1996). The northernmost location is the town of Larache, while the southernmost population is known from the north-eastern part of the salt marshes of Oualida (Crochet and Geniez 2003). The species may range further south than Oualidia, and this possible range extension requires further investigation. P. varaldii is not found above 350 m asl.
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Not Applicable (NA)
EU 27 regional assessment: Not Applicable (NA)

This species is considered Not Applicable for the European Red List as it is only known in the EU 27 from an unconfirmed record from the Spanish North African territories.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
Threats in Melilla, if the species is present, are not known.

Globally, the major threats include habitat loss and degradation due to the conversion of land to livestock pasture, and the pollution of stagnant waters with livestock droppings (Schleich et al. 1996). In addition, arable agriculture may be leading to the loss or disturbance of the sandy substrate soil habitat, with which the species is strongly associated. Populations of the species are now often restricted to temporary ponds, and those remaining in permanent waterbodies are being eliminated through the presence of predatory fishes (specifically Gambusia holbrooki).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: The species is not used or traded.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati: Under the name of Lissotriton vulgaris this species is included into the European legislative (listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention) and protected by national legislation the countries of occurrence.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: Occurs in small, relatively shallow ponds (up to 100 cm deep), connected to irrigation ditches, with still or very slow moving water and aquatic vegetation included reeds, flooded grass and a small amount of unidentified pond weed (Raxhworthy 1988). Terrestrial habitats include rough grassland, scrub and arable land (Raxhworthy 1988). It is very common among dense filamentous algae in drinking springs near roads (S.N. Litvinchuk and D.V. Skorinov pers. com. October 2022). Marmara region is an important industrial region in Türkiye. This factor affects natural habitats of this species negatively. In Thrace, intensive agricultural chemical use also affect local populations of this species negatively (N. Üzüm and K. Olgun pers. com. December 2022).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is very common and abundant species in both European and Asian parts of Türkiye (S.N. Litvinchuk and D.V. Skorinov pers. com. October 2022). There are no specific information on population status in in Greece and Bulgaria.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is endemic to Europe, where it occurs in northeasternmost Greece (Thrace and Samothraki Island; eastern Macedonia region is listed by E.-A. Toli [Greece national Red List] but is uncertain and not mapped here), southeastern and possibly central Bulgaria and Turkish Thrace (Türkiye-in-Europe) (Speybroeck et al. 2016, Wielstra et al. 2018, Baran et al. 2021, Skorinov et al. 2022). Its EOO in Europe covers 76,792 km², where 42,500 km² belong to the EU 27 region.

Out of the European region, the range of this species extends east to western Anatolia (Bursa, Balıkesir, Çanakkae, İzmir, Manisa provinces), Asiatic Türkiye (Wielstra et al. 2015, Baran et al. 2021).

Further research is required to fully understand the limits of its range both globally and within Europe in relation to other species in the genus.
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

Schmidtler's Smooth Newt (Lissotriton schmidtleri) occurs in southeastern Europe, although its exact distribution in parts of its range requires confirmation with respect to other taxa. It is assessed as Least Concern, both on the territory of Europe and within EU 27, because of its large extent of occurrence (EOO) and absence of any significant population or distribution area decline.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: No specific threats for this species were recorded, but the common threats listed earlier for L. vulgaris in the countries of occurrence of L. schmidtleri apply also for this taxon: Degradation of habitat and loss of breeding sites, caused by both climate change and human alteration, and pollution of aquatic habitats (Sotiropoulos and Lymberakis 2015, Olgun and Üzüm 2015, Tzankov and Popgeorgiev 2015). A rapid local decline in the abundance due to the intensive growth of the city has been noted in the west of Istanbul, where it was common in the early 2000s (for example, Halkali and Küçükçekmece stations), and now it is extinct (S.N. Litvinchuk pers. com. October 2022).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: The species is not utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is recorded in a national and subnational Red Data Books and Lists. In Greece, the species occurs in several protected areas: Lemnos - GR4110001 and SPA site GR4110006; Lesvos - GR4110004, GR4110003 (also SPA sites GR4110012 and GR4110010). The presence in protected areas in European Türkiye is not confirmed.

Research Needed
Further presence and status surveys are needed in parts of its range or potential range. The potential occurrence of the species in adjacent parts of Bulgaria requires confirmation through the study of specimens from this part of its potential range. Confirmation of the distribution in Turkish Thrace is also needed.

Conservation Needed
Long-term monitoring throughout the species range.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
The precise habitat use in the European part of its range is uncertain, and the habitats coded here are from the global range of the species. It is a largely fossorial species. Across its global range, the terrestrial habitats occupied are generally open uncultivated lands such as light forests, steppe (and steppe-like habitats), semi-desert and rocky areas. It is generally less selective than Pelobates fuscus in terms of soil preference, inhabiting not only soft soils suitable for a fossorial life (although they are preferred) but also solid, rocky soils, particularly friable clay with pebbles. Spawning sites include stagnant temporary waterbodies; river or lakeside temporary waterbodies and large permanent pools. It can occur in slightly modified areas, including intensively grazed areas. Its habitat is in continuous decline across its European range.

Average clutch sizes can exceed 9,000 eggs, of which less than 1% are estimated to survive to metamorphosis, and survival of juveniles in the first year post-metamorphosis is thought to be very low (S. Gafny unpubl. data). The tadpoles require a long development period of three months (Disi et al. 2014).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
In Greece, the subpopulation on Kos, one of the three East Aegean islands where the species occurs, is strongly declining due to intensive habitat alteration for tourism and is on the brink of extinction there (I. Strachinis pers. comm. November 2022). It is considered to be severely fragmented as there is no genetic flow between the islands and the subpopulations on the islands are small and localised. A population reduction of 20% is suspected to have occurred in Greece in the past three generations, and this is suspected to increase in the future.

Nothing is known about the population size and trend of this species in European Türkiye.

Across its global range, the species appears to be uncommon and a number of its subpopulations are highly fragmented and subject to significant population fluctuations, especially in the south of its range. An overall decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
In the European region, this species is restricted to a small number of records. Two of them are from the European part of Türkiye (Elmacik and Domurcali). In the Greek East Aegean, the species occurs at the northeast part of Lemnos Island (Dufresnes et al. 2019), on the northwest side of Lesvos Island and in one location on Kos Island (Strachinis and Roussos 2016, Dufresnes et al. 2019; I. Strachinis pers. comm. November 2022). Its presence in Bulgaria requires confirmation so is not included in this assessment, and its possible range there is included as 'Presence Uncertain' in the map.

The species has an extensive range out of the European region, extending through Anatolia (Türkiye) to the Caucuses and northern Iran, and south through western Syria to Lebanon (Hasbani Valley and in the Bekaa Valley near the Aammiq marsh), Israel and the West Bank of Palestine. The species is probably extinct in Jordan where it has not been observed since 1984; Disi et al. (2014) consider that it had become extinct in Jordan in the last thirty years following the loss of its last known locality. Records from northern Iraq require confirmation. At the global scale, the species occurs from 26 m below sea level (Cham-Kaleh Seashore, Gilan Province, Iran (Safaei-Mahroo and Ghaffari 2020) to above 2,000 m asl.
RedListRationale.value:
European regional assessment: Near Threatened (NT)
EU 27 regional assessment: Endangered (EN)

In Europe, this species is restricted to a small number of records from the European part of Türkiye and on three Greek islands - Lemnos, Lesvos and Kos. In Greece, it is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 20%, and the continuing decline in suitable habitat in European Türkiye suggests that it could be in decline there too. On this basis, the Syrian Spadefoot is precautionarily listed as Near Threatened under criterion A for the Europe region.

It is assessed as Endangered under criterion B (B2ab(i,ii,iii,iv,v)) for the EU 27 region as its area of occupancy in Greece is 60 km², it is considered to be severely fragmented, and the habitat area, extent and quality, number of subpopulations and number of mature individuals are undergoing continuing decline.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The species is generally threatened by habitat destruction through drainage or loss of breeding wetlands and conversion of land to agricultural and industrial use, and related water pollution but the scale and impact of these threats in European Türkiye are not known.

In European Türkiye, forested and semi-natural areas have been destroyed over the years, particularly due to the expansion of artificial areas, which continue to increase. The Ergene River basin is the most important aquatic habitat in the Thrace region and is intensively exposed to agricultural, domestic and industrial pollution (Tokatlı and Atılgan Helvacıoğlu 2020).

There is high negative impact of tourism development on suitable habitats of this species in the Greek part of its range, and it is very vulnerable to land alterations and pollution (I. Strachinis pers. comm. November 2022).

Climate change is having a significant impact on wetlands in the region, and this may impact the species (Cohen et al. 2021).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.
